name: Self-Contained Systems with microservices
description: The Self-Contained Systems (SCS) with microservices is an architecture style focussing on separation of functionality into many independent sub-systems, making our productline/products a collaboration of such software sub-systems. This avoids the problem of large monoliths that grow constantly and eventually become unmaintainable. This architecture style combines the benefits of monolithic patterns as well as microservice patterns and keeps the potential complexity of a pure microservice architecture under control.

name: Domain Driven Design
description: Use Domain Driven Design concepts and principles for decomposing our application/solution into sub-systems which are responsible for entire life cycle of thier domain.

name: Arc42
description: Arc42 is our standard way for documenting and communicating software and system architectures.

name: Infrastructure as code
description: Although infrastructure as code is a relatively old technique, it has become vitally important in the modern cloud era where the act of setting up infrastructure has become the passing of configuration instructions to a cloud platform. When we say "as code" we mean that all the good practices we've learned in the software world should be applied to infrastructure. Using source control, adhering to the DRY principle, modularization, maintainability, and using automated testing and deployment are all critical practices. Those of us with a deep software and infrastructure background need to empathize with and support colleagues who do not. Saying "treat infrastructure like code" isn't enough; we need to ensure the hard-won learnings from the software world are also applied consistently throughout the infrastructure realm.

name: API Management
description: We are strongly moving towards API First strategy treating our APIs as first-class-citizens. As we setup more and more SCS, the amount of exposed APIs grow with heavy magnitute and require an API Management tool. With this tool, we want to have a centralized control on our APIs including life cycle management, analytics, access control, monetization, and developer portal. Our APIs are defined using OpenAPI Specification (OAS) standard and we recognize this to be most popular open-source framework for defining and documenting REST APIs.

name: Multi-Tenancy
description: We commit ourselves in developing/modernizing our applications (and its architecture) to be multi-tenant in nature.

name: SaaS Deployment model
description: We commit ourselves for SaaS deployment model and be its advocates in our domains/ products allowing us (as a company) to centrally host as well as use cloud benefits at its full stength.

name: Hybrid Deployment model
description: In our journey of modernizing products towards cloud-nativeness, we will still be required to support our proprietary/classic sub-systems resulting in co-existance of cloud-native sub-systems and proprietary/classic sub-systems. During this transformation phase as well as to ensure constant transformation progress, a Hybrid Cloud setup is intended to be used where newly developed/modernized sub-systems will be operated in a SaaS model connecting to our proprietary/classic sub-systems potentially operating in private/customer data-centers.

name: 2-Factor Authentication
description: 2-Factor Auth for our web and mobile apps.

name: Client Side Load Balancing
description: Client Side Loadbalancing ensure fail-safety in production by reaching one of multiple instances of the same application where the caller (aka the client) handles the load balancing by using well established frameworks like Spring Cloud LoadBalancer, Spring Cloud Ribbon, Spring Cloud OpenFeign

name: Feature toggle
description: Feature toggles are powerful technique to modify system behavior without changing code and allows going towards Continuous Integration. We recommend using frameworks like Unleash or FF4J. Unless A/B testing or canary release are required, we encourage to use the simplest possible feature toggle instead of unnecessarily complex frameworks.

name: Strangler Pattern
description: Strangler Pattern to incrementally transform out monolithic application into Self-Contained Systems.

name: Test Driven Development
description: Test Driven Development (TDD) as a test-first practice when developing our applications.

name: Micro frontends
description: Micro-frontends extends the concepts of microservices to the frontend world. The idea is to think about a web app as a composition of features which are owned by independent teams. Each team has a distinct area of business it cares about and specialises in. Micro-frontends can be implemented using various web programming frameworks like React.js, Angular.js or even a combination of these (only as part of deliberate transition strategy, in other words avoid microfrontend anarchy). We're confident this style will allow our organization to decompose UI and enable parallel development across multiple teams.

name: Consumer Driven Contracts
description: Consumer Driven Contracts are an essential part of a mature microservices testing portfolio, enabling independent service deployments. Frameworks like pact, spring-cloud-contract are intented to be used as they make proper contract tests easier to implement.

name: Server to Client Events
description: In order to achieve near-realtime, reactive web and mobile applications, server to client communication patterns are supported by using tools and platforms like WebSockets , Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM).

name: OpenMessaging
description: OpenMessaging for selecting our streaming and messaging tools and to avoid cross tool compatibility issues.

name: CloudEvents
description: CloudEvents is a specification for describing event data in a common way, especially in serverless applications

name: Chaos Engineering
description: Chaos Engineering will allows us to experiment our cloud-native softwares and build confidence in withstanding unexpected conditions.

name: Content Security Policies
description: Content Security Policy to prevent cross-site scripting (XSS), clickjacking and other code injection attacks in our trusted web pages.

name: Spring Eco-System
description: Spring eco-system is our default preferred choice for developing cloud-native java-based enterprise applications. Its modular nature and support for diverse application infrastructure needs (via its sub-projects like Spring Boot, Spring Cloud, Spring Integration, Spring Security, Spring Session, Spring Scheduling, Spring Kafka, Spring Vault) makes it our preferred platform for developing cloud-native applications.

name: Quarkus
description: Quarkus with its amazingly fast boot time, incredibly low memory footprint and high density memory utilization in container orchestration platforms is a very attractive alternative for developing cloud-native java based enterprise applications.

name: Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM)
description: With Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) we setup reliable and battery-efficient connection between our server and devices allowing us to deliver and receive messages/notifications on iOS, Android, and the web at no cost.

name: OpenTelemetry
description: OpenTelemetry is an open source observability project that merges OpenTracing and OpenCensus. The OpenTelemetry project includes specification, libraries, agents, and other components needed to capture telemetry from services to better observe, manage and debug them. It covers the three pillars of observability — distributed tracing, metrics and logging (currently in beta) — and its specification connects these three pieces through correlations; thus you can use metrics to pinpoint a problem, locate the corresponding traces to discover where the problem occured, and ultimately study the corresponding logs to find the exact root cause. OpenTelemetry components can be connected to back-end observability systems such as Prometheus and Jaeger among others. Formation of OpenTracing is a positive step toward the convergence of standardization and the simplification of tooling.

name: OpenAPM
description: OpenAPM is an open source initiative providing a great amount of diverse technologies, utilities and tools that excellently address different, partial aspects of Application Performance Management. Combining these aspects and strengths, the tools allows for building APM solutions that are tailored to our individual product needs.

name: Event Mesh
description: Event mesh is an architectural layer that routes events from producer to consumer no matter where our apps are deployed and is composed of a network of event brokers. As we are heavily moving towards modernizing our applications to be cloud-native in nature, we will require to support hybrid setup where modernized sub-systems are running in the cloud and classic applications continue to run in on-prem datacenters. Event mesh allows us to seemslesly connect these applications without being aware of their execution in different environment/datacenters. Usage of tools like Solace, Apache Kafka and/or Apache Pulsar bring us towards Hybrid/multi-cloud event distribution and management.

name: Node.js
description: Node.js being cross-platform, JavaScript runtime environment executing at back-end is an alternative for developing webserver based containerized enterprise applications.

name: PowerBI
description: PowerBI is one promising BI Platform providing us enriched reporting capabilities in satisfying our cusotmer requirements to move towards self-service reporting.

name: Tableau
description: Tableau as a BI and Analytics leader provides built-in visual best practices, limitless data exploration possibilities, actionable analytics. It is a promising choice for our centralized analytics platform.

name: Kubeedge
description: Kubeedge is a promising platform we intend to assess and use in our journey to enable Edge computing in our applications.

name: OpenYurt
description: OpenYurt is a promising platform we intend to assess and use in our journey to enable Edge computing in our applications.

name: Tyk API platform
description: Tyk as an API platform, is a set of tools to manage lifecycle of our application APIs (internal, partnet and even commercial public APIs).

name: JEE
description: Java EE is used only for maintaining already existing multi-tiered enterprise application. New developments must avoid its usage.

name: Postgresql
description: Postgresql is a powerful, open source object-relational database system with strong reputation for reliability, feature robustness, and performance. It is our preferred object relational datastore.

name: MariaDB
description: MariaDB is one of the most popular open source relational databases and it is part of most cloud offerings. It is built upon the values of performance, stability, and openness. Recent new functionality includes advanced clustering with Galera Cluster 4, compatibility features with Oracle Database and Temporal Data Tables, allowing one to query the data as it stood at any point in the past.

name: Hazelcast
description: Hazelcast is an open source distributed in-memory data store, highly optimized and with low latencies used as a distributed cache in our event-driven and distributed services. With its simplicity to form cluster and ability to automatically replicate data across the cluster (adding seemless failure tolerance), it is our preferred choice.

name: Keycloak
description: Keycloak is an open source Identity and Access Management (IAM) tool aimed at modern applications and services. It makes easy to secure applications and services with little code and has rich capabilities like Single-Sign On, Identity Brokering, Social Login and User Federation. It is based on standard protocols and provides support for OpenID Connect, OAuth 2.0, and SAML.

name: Apigee
description: Apigee is a platform for developing and managing APIs and provides an abstraction to our backend service APIs, security, rate limiting, quotas, analytics, monetization enabling us to move faster in our API-led innovations.

name: Kafka
description: Kafka our primary event streaming and message broker for event-driven applications.

name: Drools Business Rule Engine
description: Drools is one of the most popular Business Rules Management Systems (BRMS) solution and its Business Rule Engine massively supports customizable legal regulations to be incorporated in our products.

name: Camunda BPMN Engine
description: Camunda, an opensource workflow automation tool allows automating our business processes and achieve digital transformation.

name: SonarQube
description: SonarQube for continuous code inspection to enable code quality and security.

name: Checkmarx
description: Checkmarxto scans source code and identify security vulnerabilities within the code like SQL Injection, XSS etc.

name: MongoDB
description: MongoDB is our default choice for document based distributed database.

name: Cassandra
description: Cassandra is our default choice for distributed, wide column store.

name: HBase
description: HBase is our default choice for distributed, scalable big data store.

name: Neo4J
description: Neo4J is our default choice for distributed, scalable graph database.

name: Keda
description: Keda is a promising component for enabling auto-scaling in our event-driven workloads running in Kubernetes environment.

name: Kaniko
description: Kaniko is our preferred choice for building container images. It does not depend on Docker daemon and creates container images in userspace.

name: Containerd
description: Being a CNCF graduated project, ContainerD is our preferred choice of container runtime.

name: CoreDNS
description: CoreDNS is our prefered choice for DNS and Service Discovery when running applications in Kubernetes clusters.

name: JMeter
description: JMeter is our designated service performance testing tool.

name: SoapUI
description: SoapUI is our preferred tool for automating API testing.

name: HAProxy
description: HAProxy one of our preferred ApiGateway and Service Proxy.

name: SpringCloudGateway
description: Spring Cloud Gateway one of our preferred ApiGateway when developing our applications with Spring eco-system.

name: OWASP Dependency-Check
description: OWASP Dependency Check to detect publicly disclosed vulnerabilities contained in our application dependencies.

name: Mural
description: MURAL is a "digital workspace for visual collaboration" and allows teams to interact with a shared workspace based on a whiteboard/sticky notes metaphor. Its features include voting, commenting, notes and "follow the presenter." We particularly like the template feature that allows a facilitator to design and then reuse guided sessions with a team.

name: Open Policy Agent (OPA)
description: Open Policy Agent (OPA) has rapidly become a favorable component of many distributed cloud-native solutions that we build for our clients. OPA provides a uniform framework and language for declaring, enforcing and controlling policies for various components of a cloud-native solution. It's a great example of a tool that implements security policy as code. We've had a smooth experience using OPA in multiple scenarios, including deploying resources to K8s clusters, enforcing access control across services in a service mesh and fine-grained security controls as code for accessing application resources. A recent commercial offering, Styra's Declarative Authorization Service (DAS), eases the adoption of OPA for enterprises by adding a management tool, or control plane, to OPA for K8s with a prebuilt policy library, impact analysis of the policies and logging capabilities. We look forward to maturity and extension of OPA beyond operational services to (big) data-centric solutions.

name: Serverless Workflow
description: Serverless Workflow defines a declarative and domain-specific workflow for orchestrating our event-driven and distributed services.

name: Okta
description: Okta is an Identity and Access Management (IAM) tool providing capabilities to manage and secure user authentication in modern applications, and for developers to build identity controls into applications.

name: Auth0
description: Auth0 is a flexible, drop-in solution to add authentication and authorization services to out applications. We believe it can assist in avoiding cost, time, and risk that comes with building own solution to authenticate and authorize users.

name: ADFS OIDC
description: AD FS enables Federated Identity and Access Management by securely sharing digital identity and entitlements rights across security and enterprise boundaries. AD FS extends the ability to use single sign-on functionality that is available within a single security or enterprise boundary to Internet-facing applications to enable customers, partners, and suppliers a streamlined user experience while accessing the web-based applications of an organization.

name: Spiffe
description: As a CNCF incubating project, Spiffe is a universal identity control plane for distributed systems, supports securing microservice communications and authentication to common database.

name: Veracode
description: Veracode manages security risk across entire application portfolio including SAST, DAST, SCA, and manual penetration testing.

name: Solace
description: Solace is a promising event mesh platform.

name: WebSocket
description: We intend to introduce usage of Websocket for building interactive and responsive WebApps.

name: Podman
description: Podman is a promising alternative, as being daemonless, to build/deploy/run application using OCI containers.

name: Consul
description: Consul is interesting in area of providing Service Discovery for our micro-services running in a mix of Kubernetes cluster and VMs.

name: EnterpriseDB
description: EDB as an intermediate tool to migrate from OracleDB to PostgreSQL.

name: Hashicorp Sentinel
description: Hashicorp Sentinel as an embeddable policy as code framework to enable fine-grained, logic-based policy decisions is a promising tool we envison to assess and use.

name: JFrog Xray
description: JFrog Xray a multi-layer analysis tool for detecting vulnerabilities and license complaince issues in our software artifacts and containers.

name: Mashery
description: Mashery delivers rich capabilities to our API Management requirements and we believe it will enable us towards API-led innovations, agility, new business models and setting up a digital business platform.

name: Nats
description: Nats is high performance open source messaging system for cloud native, IoT and microservice applications.

name: Pulsar
description: Pulsar open source cloud-native, distributed messaging and streaming platform.

name: Couchbase
description: Couchbase is an alternative key-value and document-oriented NoSQL database.

name: CouchDB
description: CouchDB is an alternative document-oriented NoSQL database.

name: Apiman
description: Being an open source API Management toolset, Apiman is a promising choice for publishing our APIs, enforcing thier usages, controlling access and monetization of commercial APIs.

name: TiKV
description: TiKV is a distributed transactional key-value database, a graduated CNCF project and a promising alternative to our NoSQL approach.

name: AppDynamics
description: AppDynamics has been around as market leader and we want to evaluate its use in our distributed applications.

name: DataDog
description: DataDog is another APM tool we want to evaluate its usage in our distributed applications.

name: InspectIT
description: InspectIT is an open source APM tool and we want to evaluate its usage in our distributed applications.

name: Envoy
description: Envoy is an interesting choice for us due to it being an edge proxy, service proxy as well as a communication bus designed for large microservice “service mesh” architectures.

name: Kong
description: Kong is an interesting choice as an ApiGateway / ApiMiddleware for our distributed microservice architectures.

name: Chaos Mesh
description: Being a CNCF project, Chaos Mesh is a promising choice for enabling chaos engineering in our cloud-native products/projects.

name: Chaoskube
description: Chaoskube is another choice for Kubernetes environment where it kills pods randomly and at random times to test the recovery of our application.

name: Litmus Chaos
description: Litmus Chaos is a promising toolset to do cloud-native chaos engineering. Fixing found bugs/vulnerabilities will lead to increased resilience of our application and/or surrounding infrastructure.

name: Docker
description: Docker is to be used only if a managed Kubernetes transparently uses it as container runtime.

name: Artemis
description: Artemis as message broker for JMS, JNDI and as next generation of ActiveMQ.

name: DynamoDB
description: DynamoDB due to it being Amazon proprietary NoSQL database, we currently prefer other open-source managed NoSQL stores.

name: ServiceMix
description: Avoid using ServiceMix whilst modernizing legacy applications towards cloud-native applications.

name: Oracle
description: Usage of Oracle Database must be carefully evaluated in our new/modernized cloud-native applications due to its license model & high costs.

name: GraphQL
description: As GraphQL operates on a single endpoint, defining route specific authorization, throttling, caching logic rules is quite impossible. We want to hold on using GraphQL as our ApiGateway solution.

name: Java
description: Java is a class-based, object-oriented programming language that is designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible. It is a general-purpose programming language intended to let application developers write once, run anywhere meaning that compiled Java code can run on all platforms that support Java without the need for recompilation.

name: ReactJS
description: ReactJS is an open-source, front end, JavaScript library for building our user interfaces or UI components. It is used as a base in the development of single-page micro frontends or mobile applications.

name: Angular 9
description: AngularJS is a JavaScript-based open-source front-end web framework used for developing our Web UIs.

name: React Hooks
description: React Hooks have introduced a new approach to managing stateful logic; given React components have always been closer to functions than classes, Hooks have embraced this and brought state to the functions, instead of taking function as methods to the state with classes. Based on our experience, Hooks improve reuse of functionality among components and code readability. Given Hooks’ testability improvements, using React Test Renderer and React Testing Library, and their growing community support, we consider them our approach of choice.

name: Single SPA
description: Single SPA is our preferred choice for developing micro-frontends.

name: Liquibase
description: Liquibase for tracking, versioning and deploying database changes in an automated fashion and without manual interventions. Supports one of the most attractive feature, to roll changes back and forward from a specific point — saving our operations team from knowing what was the last change/script executed on a specific DB instance.

name: Atomikos
description: Atomikos our light-weight distributed transaction management library in self-contained cloud native applications.

name: Protobuf
description: Protobuf our language-neutral, platform-neutral, binary object serialization framework.

name: resilience4j
description: resilience4j is our lightweight fault tolerance library for Java 8 programming language based sub-systems.

name: Quartz Scheduler
description: Quartz is our preferred job scheduling framework for java based applications.

name: Logback for SLF4J
description: Logback, our logging framework for java applications.

name: Log4j2 for SLF4J
description: Log4j2, our alternate logging framework for java applications.

name: GoLang
description: Golang is an open source programming language that makes it easy to build simple, reliable, and efficient software. Its concurrency mechanisms make it easy to write programs that get the most out of multicore and networked machines, while its novel type system enables flexible and modular program construction. Go compiles quickly to machine code yet has the convenience of garbage collection and the power of run-time reflection. It's a fast, statically typed, compiled language that feels like a dynamically typed, interpreted language.

name: Flyway
description: Flyway is an open-source tool helps in implementing automated and version-based database migrations. It allows us to define the required update operations in an SQL script or as Java code and can be run from a command line client or automatically as part of build process or integrated into our Java application.

name: Pistacheio
description: Pistacheio is for applying HTTP and REST layer on alredy existing C/C++ application. This allows us to gradually migrate/modernize our products heavily using C/C++.

name: Micrometer
description: Micrometer is a vendor neutral metric facade for our JVM based applications.

name: Kryo
description: Kryo our binary object serialization framework for Java based applications.

name: OpenMetrics
description: OpenMetrics is the de-facto standard for transmitting metrics and we want to evaluate its usage in our distributed applications.

name: .NET/C#
description: .Net is a free, cross-platform, open source developer platform for building many different types of applications. With .Net, you can use multiple languages, editors, and libraries to build for web, mobile, desktop, games, and IoT. We envision to write .Net apps in C# which is a simple, modern, object-oriented, and type-safe programming language.

name: VueJS
description: Vue.js is an open-source model–view–viewmodel front end JavaScript framework for building user interfaces and single-page applications.

name: Python
description: Python to be used as preferred language for MachineLearning as the availability of libraries and open source tools make it ideal choice for developing ML models.

name: Bitronix
description: Bitronix our XA transaction manager as an implementation of JTA 1.1 API.

name: Nitro
description: Nitro is a promising framework for distributed cloud-native application development in GoLang.

name: Gizmo
description: Gizmo is another promising framework for developing microservices in GoLang.

name: Microprofile
description: Microprofile is a promising framework for migrating enterprise java applications towards microservices as well as adding new features and capabilities required in migrated cloud native applications.

name: Knative
description: Knative is one of serverless orchestration framework intented to be used for developing applications with serverless architectures.

name: OpenFaas
description: OpenFaas is one of serverless framework intented to be used for developing applications with serverless architectures.

name: Kubeless
description: Kubeless is one of serverless framework intented to be used for developing applications with serverless architectures.

name: Kotlin
description: Kotlin is one promising alternative for Java based programming and we want to assess its usage possibility.

name: C/C++
description: C/C++ to be used for performance critical applications.

name: Thorntail
description: Thorntail has been declared to be at end of life and recommendation is to use Quarkus or Wildfly instead.

name: Prometheus SDK
description: Prometheus SDK allows adding instrumentation to our code. From application metrics collection point-of-view, we prefer being vendor neutral.

name: Hystrix
description: Hytrix has been put into maintenance mode and is no longer actively maintained.
